title: MoveHub: Best countries in the world for first-time home buyers
text:
AleksandarGeorgiev / Getty Images 
LONDON — Stagnant wages and rising house prices have made it increasingly difficult for first-time homebuyers around the world to get onto the property ladder.
However, the situation is improving faster in some countries than others.
Relocation firm MoveHub has compiled a ranking of the fastest-improving countries to buy a first home, by cross-referencing projected salary progression against property price increases in the last year.
The property data used was the Global Property Guide and salary projections were based on the Hays Group Salary Forecast 2016. 
Given rocketing house prices over the past two decades, the UK is the 16th worst country on the ranking — but there are some surprises in the top 5.
Take a look at the countries which made the list:
View As: One Page Slides 5. Italy — House prices fell by 0.9% last year while wages grew by 2.1%. It seems that now is a good time to invest in Italian real estate. The market has been declining for almost a decade, but investors are starting to turn towards hard assets in the wake of a domestic bank crisis and uncertainty caused by Brexit. Rome. Pixabay 4. Switzerland — Property prices dropped by 0.7% in Switzerland over the last twelve months, while salaries rose by 2.5%. Despite the improving situation, properties still do not come cheap: the median asking price for single-a family home last year was single-family homes was £970,000 ($1.2 million). AleksandarGeorgiev / Getty Images 3. Singapore — House prices in the southeast Asian sovereign city-state declined by 3.4% last year while wages grew by 3.7% thanks to the resilience of its open, trade-dominated economy — even while neighbouring China experienced a significant slowdown in economic growth. Flickr/aotaro 2. Greece — House prices fell by 4.1% last year while wages rose by 3.4%. House prices have fallen in Greece for the past seven years as the country grapples with a huge government-debt crisis which has driven down wages, pushed up unemployment, and killed buyer sentiment — apartments in Athens currently sell for as little as £20,000 ($25,000). Mateus Alves/Flickr 1. United Arab Emirates — The nation took the top spot after its property market experienced a slump in value of -7.96%, and wages grew by just under 1%. The recent sharp decline in home prices in some of the country’s hotspot cities suggests that the affordability gap is closing considerably quicker in comparison to other international regions.
